I loved the coconut-steamed fluffy rice and the simple Asian slaw. I have to get my vegetables on, so it's a must-ask question for me at every place: "does this come with a lot of vegetables?" I like that most Asian places incorporate meat and veggies very well together. This is very hard to get right at American establishments as I'm simply pointed to the vegetarian menu, but that's not what I want.  Hubs got the bun cha which had pork that was way too thinly sliced. I think Spice Island is good at the Thai/Malaysian/Singapore cuisine part but falls slightly flat at the Vietnamese part. His portion was kind of small and he finished rather quickly. Mine was a decent size and filled me up. Prices were on the lower side, but not necessarily "cheap." I'm not sure what UPitt and Carnegie Mellon students are used to but "cheap" at Ohio State campus meant between $7 - $9 entrees and an optional tip. This place was more like $11 - $14 entrees and a waitstaff.  My waitress was friendly and had suggestions too. Their house hot sauce is marinated red pepper flakes and chili oil, which is the type I prefer. Fun place! Would recommend if someone else were driving and if I were in the neighborhood.

I absolutely love this place! I always get the Chaing Mai noodles (the vegetarian version). It's oily, but it's almost the best Thai food I've ever had!  Asian food never tasted so good.  It's a small place, so you might have to wait if you're going there in a big group. But the wait is totally worth it. This place is awesome!

Spice Island is a mess of a place. The menu is very hit or miss, and the wait staff is horrific. I've been told in mid February that because one person in our four person party was not there yet that not only could we not be seated in an almost empty restaurant, but that we must wait OUTSIDE. in February. in the snow. We should have just left.  Another time, we had a large party and they had found a few tables to push together. The server left to do something else, so we figured we'd help out and start moving the tables together, only to have the server return and YELL at us to put the chairs down, as if we were somehow doing something terrible and dangerous. I was left speechless.  No amount of decent food could make up for how awful the service is here, but the food is often edible, if salty. The Pork Palou (sp?) is pretty good, and I like the coconut rice. But man, I can't believe the rudeness I've put up with from that place over the years.

Been here many times and have always enjoyed the food. It's tucked away on Atwood street and looks pretty sketchy from the outside, but the inside is very cozy and nice. They can get busy at dinner time, and if you're coming with a group, your entire table must be there before they seat you. My favorite dish by far is the Java fried rice - it has a really yummy sweet soy sauce and plenty of chicken and shrimp. Portions are big too, even for lunch. My only gripe is that service can at times be unfriendly, but not every time I've been there. Make sure you bring cash because you get a 5% discount off your check!

I haven't been here in awhile. I went there couple days ago after almost two years, and it's still as good as I remember. The menu changed a little bit I tried their Burmese food. Mmmm I'm so glad I did. I went there around 11:45, first day of school for the undergrads but the restaurant isn't too pack. Thankfully we were seated right away and we barely waited for our food. The atmosphere of the restaurant is great. It is such a relaxing place with dim lights and candle. Their menu got good selection of Asian food, many things I tried prior to this review were all on point!  This time both Me and my friend both ordered their Burmese chicken curry with coconut rice. I think I inhaled it, nothing left on my plate. The chicken was sooo tender and the curry was perfect. I definitely will not wait so long again to come back.

The java fried rice is the best fried rice in Pittsburgh hands down; not overpoweringly spicy but still has a good bit of heat, and a nice mixture of shrimp and chicken.   The squash fritters are as good of a fried appetizer as you're going to get as well, plus they aren't too heavily breaded or greasy so you don't feel too unhealthy eating them.

I love their noodle dishes! It looks like a hole in the wall from the outside but don't be afraid to venture in. It has a much nicer appearance inside and you will find yourself craving their noodles at random moments.
I had their BBQ chicken, which were tasty but not  particularly good deal. I'd like to try more though, just hoping that their other items are a better deal. Service was so-so.

This is a gem in the midst of Oakland! The ambiance is very quaint and warm. The most important thing though is that the food is delicious! The popular Pad Thai is the best I've had in the city. The Thai ice tea is a must try for someone who enjoys something sweet.   One of the most important things if you're located in Oakland is that it's got to be a cheap meal, and it is!  I've been there many times and still always end up missing the front door at times because it's so inauspicious. Just remember it's on the Right of this one way street almost to Forbes Ave.

I've had 3 things here. That's because often once I really love something I will order it to death. I love the combination satay. The menu claims it is grilled on a lava rock??!! I'd like to see that. Well, whatever, it's delicious. At lunch it's one skewer chicken, 1 pork, 1 beef. At dinner you also get 1 shrimp, and you get to pay a little more.   I also had the pad thai. That's what most of my co-workers get. I say "Eh." I've had better.  I also tried my husband's Burmese BBQ chicken. Delicious, with a curry and garlic flavor, but not an overpowering flavor, plus very tender.  Finally, I love their little samosas. While they are fried, they don't seem heavy. Light and delightful, with an accompanying sweet sauce.  Oh they also have a HUGE tea menu, although I've never ordered myself a pot. But if you're into that sort of thing, they've got a big menu!  PS I don't know who said they take reservations. We just asked tonight and it was ixnay on the eservations-ray.

This is always on the top of my list for great food in Pittsburgh .  I'm never disappointed by the portions or the taste or the price.  The decor suits the rather 'hole in the wall' kind of vibe that it gives off with the mismatched chairs and the cosy tables.  The pad thai is always a great standby with a great sauce that is pretty sweet and quite red, and oh so tasty.  Everything I have ordered has been very flavorful and never overcooked.  The portions are huge, although I often find myself finishing the whole thing.  They also have a tea menu and now serve beer and wine (although they still accept BYOWine there is a $10 corkage fee).

Don't come here if you're looking for real Thai food.  The stuffs you get here is made for Americans.  I would just call their food edible.  I came here twice.  First time, my friends are drinkers and we got great service.  What I meant by that is they made sure our glasses didn't go empty.  It's not like they cared about us, they cared about making money.  The second time I came, our party didn't order any drinks.  The attitude from the servers were completely different.  The waitress came by and asked us if we were still eating while we were still chewing our food.  What a f-king bitch.  Then again, another server came by later and did the same.  They were giving us the hints to leave.  I won't be back to this place for sure since their food sucked anyway.  They get a lot of business from the University and people liked to drink.  After a couple of drinks, anything came out of their kitchen would taste good especial when they add extra sugar.  Dont' come here if you like real Thai food.
Love love love this place. I had BBQ yesterday in Memphis and needed some vegan today. This really hit the spot. Very nice staff. Great food. And the iced tea was exceptional. Will be back.

This is my favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh! A small hole-in-the-wall with wonderful food, friendly service, and cozy decor. I took my server's recommendation and ordered the Chiang Mai Noodles - it was delicious!! The dish was cooked perfectly with fresh ingredients, and just a kick of spice! The portion was very large and the price was very reasonable. Can't wait to come back!

Great food lots of choices from different countries. The other good thing about this place it is that it has a bunch of food from Burma which is very good and not very common. tastes great, excellent service and good price.

To be fair!: I have not actually entered Spice Island's House of Tea, but I did hail a ship to deliver goods to my island, but apparently the waters surrounding it were too rough for their yellow-bellied captains. Ok ok, this is an issue to take up with Wheel Deliver....(see forthcoming review, which will probably borrow some of these fantastic joke-metaphors). We also asked for them (the restaurant) to keep their stinkin' styrofoam plates and plastic forks, but our sustainable requests fell on deaf ears... The food! Was amazing! I'm speaking here of their island rice, green curry, lemongrass beef, coconut shrimp, GINGER SALAD, and ....white rice? Can't leave that out. I must say, after months of straight Thai (also amazing), this has got to be the most original "resembling-food-from-the-Asian-continent" cuisine I've tasted here in Pittsburgh.
